title: 107_hr1414
content: The "Small Business Jobs Credit Act of 2001" aims to provide a small business tax credit to promote job growth in areas experiencing population loss and low-job growth. This credit would help spur the economy and allow businesses to utilize an underutilized well-educated workforce. The "Small Business Jobs Credit Act of 2001" introduces a new category of qualified employees, including qualified small business employees in development zones. The "Small Business Jobs Credit Act of 2001" introduces qualified small business employees in development zones, defined as areas nominated for renewal communities. The "Small Business Jobs Credit Act of 2001" designates development zones with specific population, poverty rate, job growth criteria. The "Small Business Jobs Credit Act of 2001" designates development zones with specific population criteria, limiting the Secretary of Housing and Urban Development to designate no more than 100 zones with a net out-migration of inhabitants of at least 3 percent during a specified period. Special rules apply for determining the amount of credit for wages paid to qualified small business employees. The "Small Business Jobs Credit Act of 2001" designates development zones with specific population criteria. Special rules apply for determining the amount of credit for wages paid to qualified small business employees, including adjustments to the percentage of qualified first-year wages. The "Small Business Jobs Credit Act of 2001" designates development zones with specific population criteria. Special rules apply for determining the amount of credit for wages paid to qualified small business employees, including adjustments to the percentage of qualified first-year, second-year, and third-year wages based on service rendered during specific 1-year periods. The term 'qualified third-year wages' refers to qualified wages earned by an individual during the 1-year period following the previous year. Similarly, 'qualified fourth-year wages' are wages earned during the 1-year period following the third year. The term 'qualified fifth-year wages' refers to qualified wages earned by an individual during the 1-year period following the previous year, with a limit of the first $15,000 of wages. The amendments made by this section limit the amount of qualified wages that can be taken into account to $15,000 per year for individuals starting work after the enactment of the Act.
